channel.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
channel.description:
Ok so I was looking around and I found this website that is comparing Java to C#, So Evil you can take a look this and what I see from it is C# can get a little bit more into detail but what it seems is Java is faster and can be done quicker so I pick java cause it's faster I would go with faster over a little bit more detail ^_^.
Website: http://www.harding.edu/fmccown/java_csharp_comparison.html
Pk2play suggests: http://reverseblade.blogspot.com/2009/02/c-versus-c-versus-java-performance.html

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“rdelta_, post:32, topic:404907”]Both languages have their fallbacks. Hell, both languages use stacks when interpreting and executing the bytecode, so both are very slow and made for high-end users.[/quote]… neither is very slow… =/

Read full topic

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“blakeman8192, post:33, topic:404907”][quote author=meiscooldude link=topic=501911.msg3672338#msg3672338 date=1311019633]
Well, there is an old joke…

Knock Knock!
Who’s there?
… long pause …
Java!

C# is much fast Java. I don’t have a definite answer why, but I know its in part to the JVM with its ByteCode and how it gets interpreted to Machine Code compared to the CLR and how its IL [intermediate language] gets compiled [or interpreted not sure which] to Machine Code.
[/quote]

You’re fucking stupid, this had better be trolling.[/quote]
ur just mad that noobs r stylin on u!!

Read full topic

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Ghost in stack, post:29, topic:404907”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=501911.msg3679749#msg3679749 date=1311454302]

Both of them are semi compiled which means compiled and intepretated, they generate an intermediate code that is optimized for interpretation.

That’s not true. Both compile to bytecode, yes, but neither entirely interpret it during runtime. The CLR has a JIT compiler that compiles the bytecode to machine code. That’s it as far as I know. No interpreting. HotSpot has both. It will either interpret or compile based on how frequently the code is visited, and also compile code in the background.

Ruby and Python are examples where the source code is compiled to bytecode which is then interpreted; a reason why they can be significantly slower.
[/quote]
By god…java when compiled produces bytecode that is interpreted at runtime by a JVM. Many of them use a JIT compiler that converts bytecode to machine code and then runs that code to increases the interpretation speed. In fact the java source code is compiled in a two-stage process. Same goes with C#.

This is common knowledge bro ;)[/quote]
According to you, after the JIT compiler compiles the bytecode to machine code, it is interpreted. LOL OK. You clearly don’t know what you’re talking about.

If by “java source code is compiled in a two-stage process” you mean it’s compiled to bytecode at compiled time which is then either interpreted or compiled at runtime (which is what I fucking said), YES, you are right. Same goes for C#, except it isn’t interpreted at all (afaik).

Edit: Learn what “interpreted” means in this context.

Read full topic

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)

Both of them are semi compiled which means compiled and intepretated, they generate an intermediate code that is optimized for interpretation.
[/quote]
That’s not true. Both compile to bytecode, yes, but neither entirely interpret it during runtime. The CLR has a JIT compiler that compiles the bytecode to machine code. That’s it as far as I know. No interpreting. HotSpot has both. It will either interpret or compile based on how frequently the code is visited, and also compile code in the background.

Ruby and Python are examples where the source code is compiled to bytecode which is then interpreted; a reason why they can be significantly slower.[/quote]
By god…java when compiled produces bytecode that is interpreted at runtime by a JVM. Many of them use a JIT compiler that converts bytecode to machine code and then runs that code to increases the interpretation speed. In fact the java source code is compiled in a two-stage process. Same goes with C#.

This is common knowledge bro

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Ghost in stack:

Both of them are semi compiled which means compiled and intepretated, they generate an intermediate code that is optimized for interpretation.

That’s not true. Both compile to bytecode, yes, but neither entirely interpret it during runtime. The CLR has a JIT compiler that compiles the bytecode to machine code. That’s it as far as I know. No interpreting. HotSpot has both. It will either interpret or compile based on how frequently the code is visited, and also compile code in the background.

Ruby and Python are examples where the source code is compiled to bytecode which is then interpreted; a reason why they can be significantly slower.

Read full topic

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:26, topic:404907”][quote author=Ghost in stack link=topic=501911.msg3679239#msg3679239 date=1311424969]

C# is much fast Java. I don’t have a definite answer why, but I know its in part to the JVM with its ByteCode and how it gets interpreted to Machine Code compared to the CLR and how its IL [intermediate language] gets compiled [or interpreted not sure which] to Machine Code.

Both are typically compiled from bytecode to machine code.

semi-compiled.
[/quote]
HotSpot VMs may decide to interpret the code if it saves time, like during startup, if that’s what you mean (although background compilation is done afaik). I suppose saying “typically” was wrong since it’s not that simple.[/quote]
Both of them are semi compiled which means compiled and intepretated, they generate an intermediate code that is optimized for interpretation.

Read full topic

Both are typically compiled from bytecode to machine code.
[/quote]
semi-compiled.[/quote]
HotSpot VMs may decide to interpret the code if it saves time, like during startup, if that’s what you mean (although background compilation is done afaik). I suppose saying “typically” was wrong since it’s not that simple.

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

[quote=“meiscooldude, post:10, topic:404907”]Well, there is an old joke…

Knock Knock!
Who’s there?
… long pause …
Java!

C# is much fast Java. I don’t have a definite answer why, but I know its in part to the JVM with its ByteCode and how it gets interpreted to Machine Code compared to the CLR and how its IL [intermediate language] gets compiled [or interpreted not sure which] to Machine Code.[/quote]
I saw a book a little while ago stating that in many situations, Java is 1.1x slower than C++, and in a few cases, Java has been found to be faster. It doesn’t matter whether it is a high or intermediate language to begin with, as they are compiled to be much closer to a low.

Getting the code compiled directly into machine code makes it highly platform depended, rather then being compiled into byte code which can be interpreted differently, depending on the machine / operating system.

That brings to the conclusion that the joke really is old. Java used to be up to x24 slower then C++, but in recent years, many performance upgrades have ensured that Java has kept up.

I honestly think that if Windows was the only operating system ever made, C# would be taken almost 100% of the time. But since other operating system have been made, and many devices not using a windows based operating system, Java has really gained popularity, and will continue to do so.

It depends on personal preference.

Read full topic

item.title: This is for Evil_ (C# .v.s. Java)
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:7, topic:404907”]I didn’t know C# had no switch fall through haha

Also, what’s the difference between a C# struct and a Java internal class?[/quote]Nope, you sure can’t. It’s because they noticed it was more-or-less causing subtle bugs because people would forget to put a break, when they really meant to have on there. Although, you can do this to have the same effect (to make it explicit so it’s what you’re actually meaning to do)

using System;

namespace Test
{
	class MainClass
	{
		public static void Main (string[] args)
		{
			int x = 3;
			
			switch(x) {
			case 1: // No code, it doesn't require a 'goto'
			case 2: Console.WriteLine("2"); goto case 3;
			case 3: Console.WriteLine("3"); break;
			default:
				Console.WriteLine("DEFAULT"); break;
			};
		}
	}
}

As for the speed thing:

reverseblade.blogspot.de

C# versus C++ versus Java performance comparison

The performance comparison of C#, Java and C++ was always a controversial subject. Many people who are unfamiliar with JIT'ed environments c...

this is showing .NET being 17.3% faster than Java (on windows) and on linux, Java is 7% faster than mono, so it’s really not a big enough difference to make you stray from the language.

EDIT:

[quote=“ziplock, post:19, topic:404907”][quote author=Shadowspkin link=topic=501911.msg3672382#msg3672382 date=1311022212]
Im not talking about speed im talking about faster to write, there is less lines to be written.

If anyone knows anything about C# no duh it’s faster in speed.
[/quote]

I actually find C# way faster and easier to write, but that’s subjective. I find it easier to understand. Although the C# docs aren’t very friendly. While Java’s docs are very well written.[/quote]I personally find the MSDN docs for C# to get more to the point than the Javadocs, I get so sick and tired of reading javadocs ;(, plus MSDN’s search feather when you are have trouble picking an API for something is quite handy.

Read full topic
